Reformation for what purpose? Lower tuition? Ways for employers to see "your work?" What good are these unless we return to the mission of higher education? And by higher education, I mean public higher education. Disregard the so-called "elite" universities. Our policies are too driven by these few institutions that serve a handful of young people and virtually no “adult” students. What we all should care about are public universities; land grant and other state funded institutions. These institutions have lost their way, and it isn't because of on-line competitors or "new" models of higher education like Minerva.  Many public universities have forsaken their mission to serve their states and to educate their citizens. Each new president develops a plan to be the next Stanford or Harvard. They eschew the responsibility to prepare teachers, nurses, and teaching undergraduates at all. It is the siren song enticing public universities to become "elite" that makes them vulnerable and creates antagonism in state legislatures.  Public higher education has a responsibility to its citizens and yet that mission seems to be of little interest to governing boards and university presidents. Reformation?  No. Let’s return to the mission of public higher education: discover new knowledge, teach that knowledge to the citizens of the state (ALL citizens of the state as the 1890 Morrill Act requires), and ensure a populace that ready for the future. Then universities will remain relevant.

You ignore the reason why people cheat.

People cheat because they're forced to perform tasks that disinterest them, in subjects that bore them; or they are required to study them for reasons that they don't accept.

I hated French. No interest in it. No talent for it. Didn't need it. Didn't want it. Didn't matter. I wouldn't have studied it had that decision been left up to me, but it wasn't. I was ordered to do it, on pain of expulsion. Had I been expelled all Hell would have broken out at home. When studying French became so overwhelmingly awful I did everything that I could to lessen the burden. So, occasionally, I cheated. And after I did I hated French even more than before; if such a thing were possible.

On the other hand, I loved electronics. Electronics fascinated me. My eyes were glued to books about that subject. It filled me with wonder. So I never cheated; not once. No need. In fact, it never crossed my mind. It never occurred to me.

Another difference between them: knowledge of French (or another foreign language) was required to graduate and receive a certificate. We were there to earn that certificate. Electronics wasn't even offered, although it was far more practical and useful, because the school's administration wasn't interested and it didn't want to hire anyone to teach it. This illustrates a central problem with institutionalized education: institutional needs take precedence. Student needs are secondary to those of the faculty and administration.

@Victor Edwards: And we all know that a TV cop show is a less biased, more accurate, and more reliable source of information than a report compiled by the Department of Justice. Who needs investigations when we have "reality" TV?

Don't schools in the U.S. teach critical thinking? At the public high school I attended in Canada decades ago, we did a set of projects that showed us that the media tends to sensationalize everything. In particular, we studied the ways in which advertisements attempt to manipulate people into buying products they don't need. (Put these two things together, and you will see that "reality" TV is aimed at keeping you glued to your TV so that you will buy the products shown during the commercial breaks. The shows are edited to be sensational and shocking; there is no reason to expect them to be an unbiased record of what really goes on out there. Moreover, who could be so naive as to think that cops behave the same way when they're alone as when they're being filmed for a major TV show?)

Apparently, not only is there critical-thinking education in U.S. public schools, but the right wing has been brainwashed to distrust anything the government says, to the point where they get their "facts" from "reality" TV.
